title: Letter: Here's what else FTX and WeWork have in common
text:
In the last few days you have reported on WeWork's ongoing massive losses and now the spectacular crash of Sam Bankman-Fried's FTX.

In her Long View (November 12) Katie Martin said such businesses are based around “hand-wavey ambitions rather than on traditional boring stuff like revenues, dividends . . . and institutional resilience”. Spot on.

But it seems also that in each case these businesses are built off the towering and hubristic egos of a relatively untested and youthful man.

Adam Neumann's ambition for his shared-office business was no less than to “elevate the world's consciousness” and Bankman-Fried saw no reason last year why FTX shouldn't acquire Goldman Sachs. It would all be comical, if it wasn't the case that many inexperienced investors suffer in such implosions.

These “emperor's new clothes” business models had something else in common. Masayoshi Son of SoftBank stood cheering them on, helping to pump up company values to $47bn (WeWork) and $32bn (FTX). Perhaps Masa's money, combined with a narcissistic young founder should be a sure-fire sign to sell and get out fast!

Charlie Metcalfe
Lisbon, Portugal

Source: 2022 'Letter: Here's what else FTX and WeWork have in common' FT.com 23 November. Used under licence from the Financial Times. © The Financial Times Limited 2022. All Rights Reserved.
